messages.text: sorry for coming late to the part, but: what exactly is the problem with instant merges?

elements.text: sorry for coming late to the part, but: what exactly is the problem with instant merges?

messages.text:
The first draft of AutoMerge actually did instant merge new versions.

During Pkg calls, we became concerned that this would cause a problem when people made a mistake in their registration, and suddenly didn't have a chance to fix the mistake before it was instant-merged.

So we added the delay.

elements.text:
The first draft of AutoMerge actually did instant merge new versions.

During Pkg calls, we became concerned that this would cause a problem when people made a mistake in their registration, and suddenly didn't have a chance to fix the mistake before it was instant-merged.

So we added the delay.

messages.text:
> I really think it's important that we have some delay before AutoMerging a PR. It's not uncommon for someone to realize a mistake is made
You can setup a timer that doesn't block the queue with the new GitHub environments/deploy restrictions. (not sure how reliable in regards to time that is yet) I'm guessing that GH's own automerge request thing will eventually make its way into the API too. Both combined would allow for a reliable on-PR automerge.

elements.text: I really think it's important that we have some delay before AutoMerging a PR. It's not uncommon for someone to realize a mistake is made

messages.text: Basically we'll trigger a new cron job after the stopwatch runs out. But we'll first check when the last cron job was. And we'll only create a new cron job if the last cron job was more than 15 minutes ago

elements.text: Basically we'll trigger a new cron job after the stopwatch runs out. But we'll first check when the last cron job was. And we'll only create a new cron job if the last cron job was more than 15 minutes ago

messages.text: I just realized: not only can we run the stopwatch on PR jobs

elements.text: I just realized: not only can we run the stopwatch on PR jobs

messages.text: But we can run it on cron jobs!

elements.text: But we can run it on cron jobs!

messages.text: So, after one cron job finishes, we can start a 20 minute stopwatch, and when the stopwatch finishes, we can use a personal access token to manually trigger another "cron" job

elements.text: So, after one cron job finishes, we can start a 20 minute stopwatch, and when the stopwatch finishes, we can use a personal access token to manually trigger another "cron" job

messages.text: Thus ensuring that we have jobs every 20 minutes

elements.text: Thus ensuring that we have jobs every 20 minutes

messages.text: This is all assuming that the scheduling for environment "wait timers" is more reliable than the scheduling for cron jobs

elements.text: This is all assuming that the scheduling for environment "wait timers" is more reliable than the scheduling for cron jobs

messages.text:
I've taken all the crazy syntax and documentation work I've been doing on `range` and put the maximum compatible set in a new package: <https://github.com/mkitti/Ranges.jl> . It's a little hacky because most of it was intended for Base, but it seems like the pull requests are stalling out.

Let me know if there are any issues with the merge or package name:
<https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/27338#issuecomment-754435146>

messages.text: The "stopwatch" functionality is now working. Basically, at the end of every AutoMerge job (PR, schedule/cron, or workflow_dispatch), we start a 20-minute timer. At the end of those 20 minutes, we use the GitHub Actions API to check to see when the last schedule/cron or workflow_dispatch job; if it was more than 15 minutes ago, we use the GitHub Actions API (authenticating with a personal access token) to trigger a new workflow_dispatch job.

elements.text: The "stopwatch" functionality is now working. Basically, at the end of every AutoMerge job (PR, schedule/cron, or workflow_dispatch), we start a 20-minute timer. At the end of those 20 minutes, we use the GitHub Actions API to check to see when the last schedule/cron or workflow_dispatch job; if it was more than 15 minutes ago, we use the GitHub Actions API (authenticating with a personal access token) to trigger a new workflow_dispatch job.

messages.text: As a result, we should have a new AutoMerge merge job being run at least every 15 minutes.

elements.text: As a result, we should have a new AutoMerge merge job being run at least every 15 minutes.

messages.text: Thanks to <@U6C5KSWAC> for helping to set this up.

elements.text: Thanks to
for helping to set this up.

messages.text: From now on, no new version PR should need to wait more than 20 minutes.

elements.text: From now on, no new version PR should need to wait more than 20 minutes.

elements.text: Keep an eye out, and let me know if you see any "new version" PR that passes AutoMerge but stays open for more than 20 minutes.

Also can we have it so it is always 5 give or take a minute while it merges.
So that never does the automerge for something else merge this PR?

Since you *know* you have 5 minutes if you want to bail on it
